subject: Art & Design
title: Roman Concrete: The Material That Built an Empire
description: One-minute skill: Roman Concrete: The Material That Built an Empire.

hook.text: The Pantheon's concrete dome has stood for 1,900 years. Modern concrete rarely lasts 100. What did Romans know?

buildup.text: Roman concrete mixed volcanic ash (pozzolana) with lime and seawater. The recipe was lost for centuries.

discovery.text: Scientists discovered the seawater created crystal structures that actually strengthen over time. Self-healing concrete.

twist.text: Modern Portland cement is strong but brittle and degrades. Roman concrete gets tougher with age.

climax.text: Researchers are now trying to recreate Roman formulas for sustainable modern construction. Ancient tech, future use.

punchline.text: The Romans didn't just build an empire. They built materials that outlasted it.

quiz.question: Why does Roman concrete last longer than modern concrete?
options: Volcanic ash and seawater created self-strengthening crystal structures
Roman buildings are underground and protected from weather
